title: 103_hr1317
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Franchise Data and Public Information Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds a lack of reliable statistical information on franchise businesses despite their growing importance in the American marketplace. This void hinders objective investigations into franchise failures. The Act aims to provide accurate statistical information on franchising to prevent franchisees from suffering losses due to misleading data. The Act aims to improve the performance of franchise systems, provide reliable information to the public, and ensure prospective investors have the necessary information to make informed decisions about investing in a franchise business. The Act aims to improve the performance of franchise systems and provide reliable information to the public. SEC. 3 focuses on national filing and data collection. Franchise sellers must file their disclosure documents with the Commerce Department, including the most recent and restrictive versions. Franchise sellers must annually file the most restrictive version of their disclosure document with the Commerce Department, which will make them available to Congress, the Federal Trade Commission, and other federal agencies upon request. Public viewing procedures will also be established. Franchise sellers are required to file their disclosure documents with the Commerce Department annually. It is prohibited for franchisors to falsely claim that the Commerce Department has reviewed or approved their disclosure document. The Commerce Department must establish procedures within 240 days for compiling statistical information on franchise ownership and practices. This includes using disclosure documents as the main source of data and categorizing information such as total franchisors and types of franchise businesses. The Commerce Department must compile statistical information on franchise ownership and practices, including types of franchise businesses, number of foreign franchisors, annual growth, turnover, and franchise failures. They will consult with relevant organizations to identify additional categories of statistical information for data analysis. The Commerce Department compiles statistical information on franchise ownership and practices, including types of businesses, foreign franchisors, growth, turnover, and failures. They use disclosure materials and questionnaires to supplement data for analysis. The Commerce Department will publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices annually, as required by this section. The report will be shared with Congress and made public through the Superintendent of Documents. SEC. 4. CENSUS DATA ON FRANCHISE BUSINESSES. The Bureau of the Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in its Business Census, consult with the Federal Trade Commission to identify franchise businesses, and submit a report within 280 days. The Bureau of Census will submit a report to Congress outlining the most cost-effective and accurate methods for collecting statistical information on franchise businesses for the Business Census. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to create rules and regulations to implement the Act, including classifications, adjustments, and exceptions as needed. The Secretary can also collect fees to cover costs related to filings. The Act defines key terms such as "advertisement," "disclosure document," and "franchise" in relation to offers or sales of franchises. The Franchise Act defines a franchise as a business arrangement where a franchisor grants a franchisee the right to sell goods or services associated with the franchisor's trademark or conform to quality standards. The franchisor sets quality standards for goods/services and shares knowledge with the franchisee. The franchisor exercises significant control over the franchisee's method of operation and requires payment or consideration from the franchisee. The term "franchisee" refers to a person granted a franchise, while a "franchisor" is a person granting a franchise or subfranchise. A "subfranchise" involves a contract where a person pays a franchisor for the right to sell franchises or provide goods/services to franchisees.
